title: 112_hr213
content: The "Regulation Audit Revive Economy Act of 2011" or the "RARE Act of 2011" imposes a moratorium on regulatory rulemaking actions by Federal agencies, with exceptions provided under section 4. Additionally, a special rule is established regarding statutory, regulatory, and judicial deadlines. SEC. 3 of the "RARE Act of 2011" extends deadlines for actions dependent on regulatory rulemaking during the moratorium period by 5 months or until the end of the moratorium. The term "deadline" refers to specific dates for fulfilling obligations under Federal statutes or regulations. The President must identify and publish postponed deadlines within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Emergency Exception allows a Federal agency head to request a waiver from regulatory rulemaking if there is an imminent threat to health or safety, or for the enforcement of criminal laws. The waiver must be approved by the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs and published in the Federal Register. The head of an agency must publish any excluded action in the Federal Register due to a certification. A civil rights exception exempts regulatory rulemaking actions from sections 2 or 3(a) if they establish or enforce statutory rights against discrimination, except for actions relying on quotas or preferences based on age, race, religion, gender, national origin, or disability status. SEC. 5. REVIEW OF RULES. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is required to review and report on rules being enforced, estimating costs and benefits, providing recommendations for reform, and detailing the number of minor and major rules in effect. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must enforce a uniform standard for figures and cost summaries in the report required by the Act. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. For purposes of this Act, "Federal agency" refers to any agency defined in section 551(1) of title 5, United States Code. "Major rule" is defined in section 804 of title 5, United States Code. The "moratorium period" starts 30 days after the enactment of this Act and ends either 14 days after the Director of the Office of Management and Budget publishes a report or two years after the enactment of this Act. The term "regulatory rulemaking action" encompasses various rulemaking activities published in the Federal Register, excluding cost-benefit analysis or risk assessment. The term "regulatory rulemaking action" excludes certain agency actions certified by the head of the agency and the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs within the Office of Management and Budget. These certified actions are limited to repealing, narrowing, or streamlining rules, regulations, or administrative processes, or reducing regulatory burdens, as well as matters relating to military or foreign affairs functions. The term "regulatory rulemaking action" excludes agency actions related to military or foreign affairs functions, statutes implementing international trade agreements, agency management, personnel, public property, loans, grants, benefits, or contracts, unless certified as routine administrative functions by the agency head and the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs. The term "rule" refers to agency actions taken by an agency that supervises and regulates certain financial institutions, credit unions, or government housing enterprises, as certified by the agency head. The term "rule" refers to agency statements that implement, interpret, or prescribe law or policy, excluding certain actions related to rates, safety of aviation. The curr_chunk discusses actions related to the safety of aviation, implementation of monetary policy, ensuring the safety of depository institutions, granting licenses or exemptions, and relieving regulatory restrictions. The curr_chunk defines terms related to agency actions, rulemaking, and licenses. The curr_chunk defines the terms "license" as a form of permission and "imminent threat to health or safety" as a condition expected to cause harm. No private right of action against Federal agencies for violations of the Act, but does not affect other available remedies under different laws.
